For preface, I'm a 22 year old veteran. Did 3 years in the army as an 11B, infantry. I didn't really do much during my time in, did a 9 month "deployment" in South Korea and promptly got kicked out after for a DUI. I recieved a General Under Honorable Conditions, which gives me everything except the GI bill. Which is fine, I guess, I was really looking forward to free college but it is what it is.

I'm mostly struggling with feelings of inadequecy. I signed up to "get some" and "fight the enemy" but there was no enemy to fight. There was no great battle or war. There was no glory to be gained. I spent years of my life training and training and training, only to be released into the civillain world with no transferable skills or knowledge gained. I can clear, dissasemble, reassemble and preform a functions check on an M240B in under a minute, but I can't understand Microsoft Excel. I can clear a jam in an M4 and engage a target in a split second, but I cant clear a paper jam in a printer. I can lead a fireteam to enter and clear a building with zero casualites, but I can't lead a team on a project for presenting a company's quarterly report.

Ultimately, I feel like I didn't do enough. I want to go back so badly, I want to be surrounded by likeminded people and have the opprotunity to fight in a combat zone. I feel like, as a soldier who signed up for a combat MOS, I didn't fufil my basic duty of participating in combat. I feel worthless and depressed. I'm hoping maybe some vets on this board might see this, but I guess I'm searching for guidance and instruction on how to enter normal life again. I got a decent job working at a factory, assembling Army vehicles, ironically. But I need more purpose in my life than just screwing the same bolts into a chassis for the next 40 years. Maybe this is just an excuse to vent, but I'm hoping there might be some vets that have gone through this before that can give me their two cents.

I'm autistic af how do I find an autistic gf that shares my obsessive interest?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27854942
Depending on how her autism manifests, you may need to be more literal than usual. To take a random example, to most people the questions "Can I hug you?" and "Would you like a hug?" are exactly equivalent. To an autistic person, they're not: the first one means "I want to hug you for my own enjoyment - can you tolerate me doing that?" the second means "Would you enjoy being hugged?" - which is not the same thing at all.

In general, things that seem extremely obvious to you will not be obvious to her. She may not fully understand social conventions. She may have trouble with non-verbal communication (for example, it may seem like she keeps interrupting you when actually she just can't tell whether you've finished speaking or not). You have to keep constantly checking yourself to make sure you aren't making unconscious assumptions. And be ready to think "Okay, she can't possibly have meant that the way it sounded, I wonder want she actually meant?" instead of just getting upset.

You should also expect her to find some things distressing which it wouldn't occur to you could be. For example, she may need objects to be kept in a particular place and not moved around (don't ever start tidying an autistic person's home without asking!) or she may not like being touched (especially without warning) or she may get overloaded by noise or crowds or certain visual stimuli.

It's difficult to be very precise about all this, because autism manifests in so many different ways. The most important thing is to give her the chance to explain what she needs from you, and actually listen when she does.

also making the obvious assumption we're all men here- you may not have learned proper usage of shampoo vs conditioner since nobody expects us to give a shit about our hair: shampoo make sure you work into your scalp, conditioner you mostly just want to get everything that's not adjacent to your scalp out to the tips.

sulfate products dry your scalp out big-time and if you've been using a head and shoulders product for as long as you remember, i would bet money it's got a bunch of sulfates in it and is making your scalp sensitive. having "greasy" hair im sure your scalp makes a shitload of sebum, which usually comes from the fact that it's overcompensating from getting dried out so much. even if you cut back on the washing and it's a problem because 1. it takes a while for your body to adjust and 2. using the same dogshit product will probably make changing habits a moot point


the face does the same thing- i used to unknowingly use a pretty harsh cleanser that would strip all the oil off my face and then an hour or two later i would have a fucking nasty ass oily face worse than if i just didnt wash. the face will overproduce sebum if you dry it the fuck out, and it'll be sensitive and react this way for a while even after you change habits/products. i stopped using that product and just used warm water to rinse my face off every morning, after a week or two, boom i have no troubles with oily skin anymore. good luck.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27855325
Professor writing here

Relax. What you did was perfectly legitimate. The only question that might be raised is whether you added enough value to this version to make it superior to the first. In other words, if it's essentially the same as the undergrad paper you might be told it isn't of Masters quality. But self-plagiarism is something all writers do. An academic paper might be expanded into a book, a short story might become a chapter in a novel, a second edition of a book might use material from the first, and so on.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Ok, I'm going to reluctantly open this tin of worms because no one else seems to be addressing the elephants in the room.

There appears to be some confusion on your part OP about the meaning of friend verse acquaintance, let alone "good friend". This confusion appears to be at the core of your problem.

An acquaintance is someone you have some conversation with, perhaps sometimes some very interesting conversations with. They are people whose ideas you might enjoy but you don't really know very well, and don't have much (if any) shared experience with. This means by definition acquaintances are people outside of ones friend group, they are held at arms length and are easily disposed of. It's where someone is when you first meet them and are deciding if you want to be their friend.

A friend is someone you know things about, whon lets you in and tells you things, whom confides in you and seeks advice, but most importantly whom actively seeks to do things together to spend time and where shared experiences have been established.

A GOOD friend is a long time friend you have many shared experiences with, know everything about and share a deep connection with.

---What you have described in your post is an acquaintance, it certainly isn't a good friend. ----

The problem you're having is you aren't making it beyond acquaintance. In many ways making friends is like dating, only the terminology changes and there's usually no sex involved. Small talk about your interest is ok to get someone on the hook, but what are you doing to create shared positive experience to bond the two of you in friendship?

Are you inviting them somewhere to do something together? Are you working on a project together? If it's just a conversation about a handful of interests it's always going to be just an acquaintance.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
[2/2] Friendships take effort, real work, to develop and maintain. People won't put in that effort unless you give them a good reason to. People are selfish creatures, they don't do anything unless their interests are served in some way. So the question is, what does someone get out of putting in the effort to transition from acquaintance to friend with you? What do they gain in you?

Are you funny? Do you have a desirable skill? Are you level headed to balance them out? Do you help validate them? Do you always invite them to cool places or throw great parties? Do you have great ideas for activities to do together that are enjoyable for both of you? What is it that makes being your friend worthwhile?

>>27852919

Don't worry, you were lowering their average and they were raising your average.
Think of it like that and both friend groups are closer to equal.
You're welcome.
